title: 114_s1276
content: The Act titled "Offshore Energy and Jobs Act of 2015" includes reforms to the Outer Continental Shelf Leasing Program. The "Offshore Energy and Jobs Act of 2015" amends Section 18(a) of the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act to require the Secretary to make at least 50% of available unleased acreage in the Gulf of Mexico available for leasing in each oil and gas leasing program. The Secretary must include State subdivisions in the Gulf of Mexico in proposed oil and gas leasing programs if requested by the State Governor. Outer Continental Shelf planning areas estimated to be prospective must be made available for leasing under each 5-year program. The Secretary must include State subdivisions in the Gulf of Mexico in proposed oil and gas leasing programs if requested by the State Governor. Outer Continental Shelf planning areas estimated to contain significant oil or gas reserves must be made available for leasing under each 5-year program, using specific criteria outlined in a designated document. Moratorium on oil and gas leasing in certain areas of the Gulf of Mexico. The amendment defines the Military Mission Line as the western border of the Eastern Planning Area in the Gulf of Mexico. It also reduces the moratorium area in the Central Planning Area to within the 181 Area or 50 miles off the coastline of the State. The amendment reduces the moratorium area in the Central Planning Area to within the 181 Area or 50 miles off the coastline of the State of Florida. The Secretary of the Interior is required to implement the Proposed Final Outer Continental Shelf Oil & Gas Leasing Program (2017-2022) according to the schedule set forth in the program and other applicable laws. Additionally, certain oil and gas lease sales will be conducted in OCS Planning Areas as specified in the schedule. Lease sales numbers 300, 301, and 302 in the Eastern Gulf of Mexico for the years 2018, 2019, and 2020 will be conducted in accordance with the applicable provisions of the Act. SEC. 5. DISPOSITION OF OUTER CONTINENTAL SHELF REVENUES TO GULF PRODUCING STATES. The Gulf of Mexico Energy Security Act of 2006 is amended to include Florida as a Gulf producing state starting in fiscal year 2017. The definition of Gulf producing state now includes Alabama, Louisiana, Mississippi, Texas, and Florida. Starting in fiscal year 2017, Florida is included as a Gulf producing state under the Gulf of Mexico Energy Security Act of 2006. This includes all rentals, royalties, bonus bids, and other payments due to the United States from leases in the Eastern Planning Area. The Gulf of Mexico Energy Security Act of 2006 is amended to allocate 50 percent of qualified outer Continental Shelf revenues to Gulf producing States, with 75 percent going to the states and 25 percent for financial assistance to other states. The Gulf of Mexico Energy Security Act of 2006 is amended to limit the total amount of qualified outer Continental Shelf revenues made available for fiscal years 2017 to 2055. SEC. 6. NATIONAL DEFENSE. National Defense Areas are designated by the Secretary of Defense on the outer Continental Shelf. No oil or gas activities under this Act should conflict with military operations as per the agreement between the Department of Defense and the Department of the Interior. Any revision or replacement of the agreement between the Secretary of Defense and the Secretary of the Interior must be agreed upon before the lease for exploration, development, or production is issued. SEC. 7. ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT STATEMENT REQUIREMENT. The Secretary of the Interior must prepare a multisale environmental impact statement for lease sales required by the Act. The statement does not need to include nonleasing alternative courses of action or analyze their environmental effects. The Secretary of the Interior is required to identify a preferred action for leasing and one alternative leasing proposal, and analyze their environmental effects and potential mitigation measures. SEC. 8. Coastal State Authorization: Gulf producing States can opt into offshore oil and gas leasing programs with legislative approval and Governor's signature. SEC. 9. Amendment to the Clean Air Act includes Florida in air emissions regulations. SEC. 10. Offshore Certainty. In this section, definitions are provided for terms like "Director," "harassment," and "request for incidental harassment authorization." The Director is defined as the Director of the National Marine Fisheries Service, harassment is defined in accordance with the Marine Mammal Protection Act, and a request for incidental harassment authorization is a submission to conduct an activity that may result in incidental harassment of marine mammals. The Director is responsible for handling requests for incidental harassment authorization. The Director must accept or request additional information for incidental harassment authorization within specific timeframes. If additional information is provided, the Director must accept or return the request within 30 days. The Director must respond to a request for incidental harassment authorization within specific timeframes. Failure to respond within the deadline means the request is considered complete. Accepted requests will be processed in accordance with the Marine Mammal Protection Act of 1972. SEC. 11. The Secretary of the Interior will amend regulations to require continuous operation for 270 days instead of 180 days. SEC. 12. Provides for expedited judicial review. The term "covered energy development" refers to actions or decisions by a Federal official regarding leasing of offshore Federal land in the outer Continental Shelf for energy exploration, production, or transmission. This section does not apply to disputes between parties to a lease regarding lease obligations or breaches. The United States District Court for the District of Columbia has exclusive jurisdiction over causes and claims related to covered energy development. Cases must be filed within 60 days of the action by a Federal official. Any cause or claim not filed within the specified time period will be barred. Proceedings subject to subsection (b) must be resolved within 180 days of filing and take precedence over other matters in the District Court for the District of Columbia. Failure to meet the deadline will result in the cause or claim being affected. If a cause or claim is not filed within the specified time period, it will be dismissed with prejudice. The District Court for the District of Columbia has the exclusive authority to review any judgments under this section. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct accurate estimates of the cost of complying with Federal rules for offshore energy production on the outer Continental Shelf and submit a report to Congress.
